name: Dichotomy
label: In The Red
review: Fuzzy solo project from LA fixture Charles Moothart, with a DIY ethic clearly in place.
related: Ty Segall, Mykal Cronin, Toadies, T-Rex

name: Wild and Weak EP
review: Whip-smart hooks, electronic frosting, and a sassy female vocalist make for a good combination.
related: Garbage, Metric, Bully

name: Add Violence
label: Capitol
review: Trent Reznor delivers more biting digial/analog fusion, with dark synth pads abetted by darker guitar tones.
related: A depressed Nintendo

name: Took Our Sons Away
label: Yippee Ki Yay
review: Garage rock revivalists from Sweden, guaranteed to make your monkey dance.
related: Mooney Suzuki, Oh Sees, Oblivians

name: Rule 62
label: Six Shooter
review: There is nothing about Whitney Rose’s country music that sets it apart from the archetype of a traditional female country singer, but great vocals and top-notch performances by an all-star cast of studio musicians make this a fun listen.
related: Dolly Parton, Tanya Tucker

name: Destroyers Of The Soft Life
label: ATO
review: Good southern-tinged rock, anthemic and singalong. Nothing ground-breaking, but top-notch songwriting and production.
related: Wilco, Drive By Truckers, The Outfield

name: The Hanged Man
review: Solo effort from longtime pop gem Ted Leo, filled with wicked hooks and his distinctive singing voice.
related: Superchunk, Spoon, the New Pornographers

name: Outrage! is Now
label: Warner
review: There’s a very straight line between classic rock and this stuff — riff heavy, loaded with hooks and dynamics, and a sense of epic scale beyond the noise that some dudes with instruments could make.
related: QOTSA, Black Sabbath, Fu Manchu, Wolfmother

name: Light Information
label: Sub Pop
review: Strange songs, played by one man with a strange voice. Science fiction alienation and lush arrangements make for an unexpected series of sonic twists and turns.
related: Ted Leo, The Left Banke, Momus

name: Tasty Waves
label: Hidden Volume
review: This trio of brothers make a racket that’s a lot of fun, and catchy as hack.
related: The Apples In Stereo, Spot 1019, Young Fresh Fellows, Nick Lowe

name: Try ;-)
label: Mint
review: A variety of sounds and moods from this duo. Yes, that is a winky emoticon in the album title.
related: Margaret Glaspy, Heartless Bastards, Liz Phair, Girlpool

name: IV
label: Knot Reel
review: It stands for “Eclecting Selections Of Everything But Opera”, but mostly smokey bluesy jazzy country stuff with some interesting additional instruments. Pronounced “Ee-so-bo”.
related: Mumford and Sons, Los Lobos, Dan Hicks

name: L.A. Witch
label: Suicide Squeeze
review: Reverb-drenched heavy rock, aptly living up to its name with a blend of rockabilly, surf, and disaffected retro-cool.
related: Dum Dum Girls, Bleached, Cramps

name: Super Ape Returns To Conquer
label: ROIR
review: Returning to the seminal “Super Ape” album after four decades, Perry proves he’s adept at new technologies as well as old techniques.
related: Jamaican dub music

name: Songs We Like
review: Jazz trio renditions of a curiously selected set of songs. Jimi Hendrix, Bartok, the Police, Led Zeppelin (twice), Steely Dan, and more all get a turn.
related: The Bad Plus

name: Dedicated to Bobby Jameson
label: Mexican Summer
review: Off-kilter washes of synth and gothic vocals amidst psychedelic folk, rushes of prog rock, and incredibly delicate moments.
related: Animal Collective, Deerhunter, Hawkwind, Luna

name: Where The Gods Are In Peace
label: Daptone
review: Great modern take on the Afrobeat genre, with a healthy dash of psychedelic punk.
related: Fela, Tony Allen, Afrobeat

name: Electric Trim
label: Mute
review: The Sonic Youth guitarist’s solo effort is not as discordant as you might expect, and features collaborations with Sharon Van Etten, Nels Cline, and Jonathan Lethem (on some lyrics)
related: King Missile, Sonic Youth

name: Half-Light
label: Nonesuch
review: The person behind Vampire Weekend’s production and half of Islands’ distinctive sound shows more of his unique sonic signature on a full album of gentle songs awash in analog and digital abstractions and heavenly choruses
related: Vampire Weekend, Islands, MGMT, Tame Impala

name: Holiday Ghosts
label: PNKSLM
review: Garage rock like it’s meant to be, full of barely-controlled fuzz, raging vocals, warbling organs, and four-on-the-floor drums.
related: Black Tambourines, The Woggles, King Khan

name: (V)
label: Epitaph
review: Classic LA hardcore served up in a blaze. An aggressive release from an aggressive band.
related: Rancid, Rocket From The Crypt, Bad Religion

name: Fantastic Plastic
label: Sonic Kicks
review: Cyril Jordan and Chris Wilson reunite to bring back the sound that made the Flamin’ Groovies famous 40 years ago with “Shake Some Action”. A solid return to form.
related: Big Star, The Plimsouls, Wilco

name: Ephrata
label: Dessert
review: Dreamgaze shoepop from this Seattle foursome that takes harmonies and production very seriously.
related: Best Coast, Cocteau Twins, Beach House

name: Strange Peace
label: Sub Pop
review: The line between a riff and a throbbing structures of pitched rhythm is pretty thin, as these Canadians show. METZ is punishing without being abusive. A Steve Albini recording.
related: Bass Drum of Death, JEFF the Brotherhood, Oh Sees, King Gizzard + TLW

name: Dumbness
label: Lame-o
review: An honest tribute to stupidity, full of hooks, snappy lyrics, and gorgeous choruses
related: Spoon, New Pornographers

name: Visions of a Life
label: RCA
review: Guitars, synths, great production, and pop hooks a-plenty.
related: The Horrors, Hole, Garbage

name: What Goes Up
review: More modern Afrobeat, connected to the source via drummer Tony Allen. A wild collection of Chicago talents united for a smoothly entrancing session of shorter (for Afrobeat) songs.
related: Fela, Tony Allen, Afrobeat

name: Outside the Comfort Zone
review: A dynamic collection of mostly-short funky jazz instrumentals, with a full horn section and a driving beat.
related: Medeski Martin + Wood, Galactic, Antibalas

name: Death by Blowfish EP
review: Four chuggy songs showing great promise. From Canada.
related: Pixies, White Stripes, Oh Sees

name: FM-2030
label: Captured Tracks
review: An eccentric selection of songs, teetering on the edges of what is considered decent girl-fronted pop.
related: Tennis, The Bird + The Bee, Cranberries

name: Boxing The Moonlight
label: Polyvinyl
review: If the aliens thought we communicated in oldies, and were trying to send us a message, this would be it.
related: The Unicorns, Man Man, Islands

name: Cry Cry Cry
label: Sub Pop
review: Dense arrangements of fragile parts, a wide palette of textures and tempos, and a pervading sense of drama make this a collection of pensive songs
related: The Decembrists, Radiohead, Beirut

name: TFCF
label: Mute
review: Down to one original member, who recorded most of this in the Australian bush, this album sounds desperate and hopeful at the same time with its strange mix of acoustic, electronic, and environmental sounds.
related: Nine Inch Nails, Swans, The National

name: Going Grey
label: Fueled By Ramen
review: The masters of punk Americana return with a highly-polished and well-produced effort.
related: Frank Turner, Future Kings of Nowhere

name: Like A Version
label: Triple J
review: A wildly careening set of covers from Australias Triple J radio megalith. Loads of fun.
related: Various Artists

name: Masseduction
label: Loma Vista
review: Annie Clarke’s strong voice floats effortlessly above a dense cascade of synthetic and organic sounds
related: Tom Tom Club, Nine Inch Nails, Annie Lennox

name: Little Darkness
label: Tender Loving Empire
review: Highly melodic and full of dramatic sweeps in dynamics, this is a collection of songs that slowly grows on you.
related: The Mabuses, Arcade Fire, Split Enz, Golden Shoulders

name: Lucky Star
review: Although you can no longer smoke in most live music venues, this will always be smokey jazz, slow-burning or quickly flaring with a lush velvety voice on top.
related: Billie Holliday, Hot Club of Cowtown

name: IIIII
label: Chugg
review: Australia’s Dappled Cities straddles the line between new wave and indie, with solid hooks and crystal-clear pop production.
related: Echo and the Bunnymen, James, early U2

name: Resurgam
label: R’Coup’d
review: Fink meanders through a variety of moody sounds, mostly brooding with flashing patches of sunshine.
related: The National, Nick Cave, Liars

name: The Details
label: Pheromone
review: A great collection of intense flavors, from easy rockers to bedroom recordings to full-on blasts
related: Juliana Hatfield, Courtney Barnett, Jenny Wilson

name: Lotta Sea Lice
label: Matador
review: Such grand disaffection from this US/AUS pairing … my new favorite Kurt and Courtney, providing the weirdest yet most natural male/female vocal duets.
related: Paleface, Juliana Hatfield, X

name: Losing
label: Sub Pop
review: Wildly dynamic outfit with in-your-face female vocals. Sounds twenty years old and completely new at the same time.
related: L7, The Muffs, The Bits

name: ken
label: Merge
review: Dan Bejar’s own project features his distinctive voice and musical mannerisms, carried over from the ‘80s.
related: The New Pornographers, New Order

name: III
label: Run For Cover
review: Swirling and pounding sounds with reverb-drenched vocals from this Swedish “post-punk” outfit
related: Lush, The Raveonettes, Savages

name: Diamante Eléctrico
label: Mercado Negro
review: Rock latino, full-on-boogie, or as they say in their native Colombia, “bugi.”
related: Los De Abajo, Los Fabulosos Cadillacs, ZZ Top

name: Plunge
label: Mute
review: Sparse and electronic, sometimes abrasive, this project from Swedish vocalist Karin Elisabeth Dreijer can be difficult and/or rewarding.
related: Bjork, Nine Inch Nails, Micachu and the Shapes

name: Let The World Be Flooded Out
label: Bitchwave
review: Intriguing set of well-crafted songs from this solo artist.
related: Ani DiFranco, Bikini Kill, Sleater-Kinney, Deerhoof, Thao and the Get Down Stay Down

name: Introduction to Escape-Ism
label: Merge
review: This is Ian Svenonius’ latest foray, a beatbox-backed recitation of lackadaisical poetry swimming in over-the-top soul delivery.
related: Nation of Ulysses, the Make Up, Ian Svenonius

name: Dollhouse
label: Cadence
review: Another stunning set of songs from these Vancouverites, full of fuzz and dynamics.
related: New Pornographers, Nirvana, The Vaccines

label: City Slang
review: The title and a first listen make you think this is a retro thing, but it is more of a weird synthesis from a group of Scandinavian musicians.
related: Liars, Fink, Tangerine Dream

name: Resilient
review: Cross-cultural collaboration mixes up a Balkan frenzy with dope beats and MC’ing
related: Shantel, Goran Bregovic, Handsome Boy Modeling School

name: Soul of a Woman
label: DapTone
review: Posthumous release from one of the strongest voices in modern soul.
related: Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Sugarman 3, old-school R&B

name: Reworks
label: Sub Pop
review: An interesting set of covers for solo piano, performed live
related: The Bad Plus, Keith Jarret

name: Thanks for Listening
label: Nonesuch
review: Thile (THEE-lee) is a world-class mandolinist who also happens to have replaced Garrison Keillor as the host of that Wobegon show. Subtle and introspective.
related: Jeff Buckley, Randy Newman

name: Songs of Praise
label: Dead Oceans
review: Aggressive debut from this UK band features some highly dynamic songs loaded with twisty hooks.
related: Failure, Killing Joke, Mudhoney, Fugazi, Parquet Courts

name: Glade
label: PNKSLM
review: More from this wave of reverb-drenched noisy Swedish psychedelia that we’re enjoying lately.
related: Thee Oh Sees, Shitkid, Holiday Ghosts

name: Dr. Demento Covered In Punk
label: Demented Punk
review: Take the most memorable weirdness to come out of Dr. Demento’s near-50-year reign and let a bunch of punks cover them.
related: What you would hear on Dr. Demento’s show

name: Modern Lore
label: Mack Avenue
review: High-order guitar instrumentals more concerned with melody and expression than pyrotechnics. Truly ear-opening.
related: John Scofield, Marc Ribot

name: Survival EP
label: Grand Analog Music
review: Soulful beats in the style of old-school acid jazz, mostly instrumental.
related: DJ Food, Dan the Automator, Ninja Tune

name: Vessel of Love
label: Merge
review: Pitch perfect UK reggae from the Slits vocalist, full of heavenly harmonies and thumping bass.
related: Steel Pulse, The Selecter

name: All These Worlds Are Yours
label: PNKSLM
review: Dense arrangements make for a hallucinatory experience as each song feels like a symphony passing you by at light speed.
related: Black Moth Super Rainbow, early Pink Floyd, Syd Barrett, Flaming Lips

name: POST-
label: Polyvinyl
review: Great singalong spirit, hot flaming hooks, and actual things to say.
related: Andrew Jackson Jihad, The Front Bottoms

name: Full Circle Nightmare
label: Sub Pop
review: A master songwriter effortlessly putting out majestic compositions that will stick in your head for weeks.
related: Ben Folds, AC Newman

name: Loma
label: Sub Pop
review: Dark and light, sparse and lush, this is an album of dynamics and contrast, fronted by an angelic female voice.
related: This Mortal Coil, Cocteau Twins, Silver Apples, Lida Husik

name: Shape The Future
label: Warp
review: If you gotta have some beats, you gotta have some Nightmares on Wax. Moody interludes for slick rainy asphalt.
related: Thievery Corporation

name: Rock Island
label: Carpark
review: Imagine your Beach Boys CD started skipping but you liked it better that way.
related: The Zombies, Papas Fritas, High Llamas

name: Starcrawler
label: Rough Trade
review: Straightahead rock, no apologies.
related: L7, Thin Lizzy, Warpaint, Bully

name: I can feel you creep into my private life
label: 4AD
review: Angular compositions and Merrill Garbus’ distinctive vocals, glued together in strange uncomfortable ways, but it all works.
related: King Crimson, St. Vincent

name: Uncle, Duke + the Chief
label: Yep Roc
review: Some of that weird pop, this time with a definite tinge of Americana, or perhaps Canadiana, since the band is from Toronto
related: My Morning Jacket, Vampire Weekend, Deertick

name: Twin Fantasy
label: Matador
review: Dense arrangements make for some slowly emerging indie orchestral music. Disc 2 is the demo versions of the songs on Disc 1.
related: Pavement, The Smiths, The Wedding Present

name: Riddles
label: Carpark
review: Heady mix of post-punk and electronic sounds, heavy on the bass riffing. Features Dan Deacon on beeps and such.
related: Dan Deacon, Liars, Lightning Bolt

name: Tomorrow’s Shore EP
label: Wichita
review: Washes of fuzzed-out bliss at your choice of tempos
related: The Jesus and Mary Chain, My Bloody Valentine, His Name Is Alive

name: All At Once
label: Don Giovanni
review: Fronted by Marissa Paternoster’s dramatic and dynamic vocals, this power trio hearkens back to the DIY indie scene
related: L7, The Gits, Bully

name: Crush
label: Olex
review: One-man band Tom Hauck is Telamor, with a variety of songs that sounds like they were lifted straight out of ‘80s college radio
related: Violent Femmes, XTC, LMNOP

name: Sluff
label: New West
review: This goes all over the place, but mostly rocks hard with inventive arrangements and infectious hooks.
related: Blur, Rocket From The Crypt, Parquet Courts

name: Loud Patterns
label: Secretly Canadian
review: An engaging hybrid of analog and electronic sounds, with occasional soulful vocals intertwined in the mix.
related: Nine Inch Nails, Daft Punk, OMD

name: Bleenex
label: Omad
review: Bewildering and enchanting solo project that can swing dramatically between lo-fi and supremely nuanced
related: Japandroids, The Unicorns, Los Campesinos!

name: Bomb Pop
label: New Garden
review: Solid power-pop outing with an all-star cast… a must for fans of the Yellow Pills series.
related: Material Issue, The Posies, The Kinks

name: Bajo el Mismo Cielo
label: Nacional
review: A Cuban transplant in Paris, this artist mixes Afro-Cuban elements with modern trap and reggaeton, spicing it up with many other influences to make for a very danceable time.
related: Buraka Som Sistema, Rosalia, Tijuana Sound Machine

name: Goat Girl
label: Rough Trade
review: Guitar-centered rock with moody female vocals, with a harder edge and good dynamics.
related: Pinback, Throwing Muses, Elastica

name: How To: Friend, Love, Freefal
label: Elektra
review: Heady mix of folk, electronic and hip hop elements swirling together into something unique and accessible.
related: Modest Mouse, Django Django, My Morning Jacket, Vampire Weekend

name: Critical Equation
label: We Buy Gold
review: The band returns with more of their particular brand of folksy psychedelia. Lots of great hooks and harmonies, as usual.
related: Born Ruffians, My Morning Jacket, ELO

name: Moosebumps
label: Bulk Recordings
review: Twenty years later, Dr. Octagon still sounds like the future of intelligent-slash-weird hip-hop
related: Kool Keith, Gorillaz, Handsome Boy Modeling School

name: When I Think Of You In A Castle
label: Polyvinyl
review: Seriously kinetic, full of unexpected musical twists and turns, and at the same time prone to laying down an excellent drone beat.
related: Thee Oh Sees, Artichoke, King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard

name: Twerp Verse
label: Carpark
review: A powerful set of guitar pop songs, fronted by sometimes disaffected indie female vocals.
related: The Rentals, Veruca Salt, Liz Phair

label: Sub Pop
review: Washes of sound surround you as half-heard vocals intertwine with half-remembered melodies.
related: Cocteau Twins, Lush, Stereolab

name: Panic Blooms
label: Rad Cult
review: Is it experimental psychedelia or is it the soundtrack to a fragmented dream? It is not necessary to decide.
related: Animal Collective, Half-Handed Cloud, The Flaming Lips

name: Inside The Flesh Hotel
label: Alive
review: Good collection of indie rock music, with influences stretching over several decades and a good variety of sounds.
related: Apples In Stereo, T. Rex, Wolfmother

name: Forth Wanderers
label: Sub Pop
review: Wildly dynamic swings of mood from this rock-format combo, filled with sweet chiming vocal harmonies set against dissonance and rhythm.
related: Breeders, Throwing Muses, Toenut, Deerhoof

name: The Other
label: Sub Pop
review: King Tuff clearly has a rock and roll heart, with the sort of grandiose expression that has a southern blues charm.
related: Led Zeppelin, Black Crowes, Billy Squier

name: Floating Features
label: Hardly Art
review: La Luz takes everything that’s great about surf rock and dreamy girl vocals, gives it a new coat of paint, fills it with high-octane, and dares you to keep up.
related: Link Wray, Shadowy Men on a Shadowy Planet, Insect Surfers

name: Winning Star Champion
label: Barsuk
review: A brilliant collection of indie pop gems, featuring the sounds and hooks that made “alternative music” so great in the first place.
related: Death Cab for Cutie, Hoodoo Gurus, Nirvana, Robyn Hitchcock

name: Welcome to Flat Earth
label: Tremolo
review: Another one-man rock act that wears its influences on its sleeve, but it’s well done so don’t take that as a complaint. Highly political.
related: Ty Segall, T. Rex, Brian Jonestown Massacre, King Tuff

name: Their Prime
label: Sub Pop
review: Somewhere beyond easy genres is this woozy mix of indie soul and post-rock complication.
related: Deerhoof, Nirvana, Sonic Youth, Thingy

name: Best Record Ever
label: Smog Veil
review: Hard-rocking, beer-chugging, smoke-breaking anthems from this Cleveland couple. They can also veer into weird and spooky.
related: Spinal Tap, The Horrors, The Raveonnettes, Julee Cruise

name: Scout EP
label: Royal Mountain
review: Some very young Canadians show plenty of promos with this pleasantly bratty set of indie guitar rock.
related: Half Japanese, Dr. Dog, Mooney Suzuki, Spice Boys

name: Lush
label: Matador
review: Bold effort from this young musician, this set of introspective songs shows great skill and promise.
related: The Sundays, Lush, Liz Phair, Madder Rose

name: Hardly Electronic
label: Merge
review: Hooks as sharp as diamonds, girl/boy vocal harmonies, jangling guitars… what else do you need to play this summer?
related: Apples In Stereo, Belle and Sebastian, Push Kings, Dressy Bessy

name: Sixth House
label: Merge
review: This southern gothic staple returns, with a bit less reverb but just as much agony and attitude.
related: My Morning Jacket, Wilco, Archers of Loaf

name: Call The Comet
label: Sire
review: Johnny Marr, who provided his distinctive liquid guitar sound to the Smiths and many others, returns with a solo album that shows not much has changed.
related: Modest Mouse, The Smiths, Jesus + Mary Chain

name: Unreason In the Age of Madness
label: Indica
review: Aggressive metal-reggae-funk, which is not something I generally like, but this one has some sort of undermined charm to it.
related: Faith No More, Sublime, Anthrax, Fishbone

artist: The Mystery of the Bulgarian Voices
name: BooCheeMish
label: Prophecy
review: A sound you could classify as ethereal, alien, or both. Ancient gregorian harmonies collide with Middle Eastern time signatures for something truly unique. Features DCD’s Lisa Gerrard
related: Enigma, Dead Can Dance, creepy film soundtracks

name: Buck Meek
label: Tiger Bomb
review: If you think a song about car repairs can’t touch your heart, you’ve never heard Buck Meek. A unique voice and an easy country rock feel.
related: Drink Me, Son Volt, Sonny Smith

name: Sound The People
label: Rhyme + Reason
review: A beat-heavy collection of international sounds, this band is literally all over the place in a boundary-pushing mix of afrobeat, bhangra, hip-hop, jazz and other genres.
related: Balkan Beat Box, Asian Dub Foundation, Antibalas

name: The Return
label: Goner
review: Cinematic expressions of synthesis collide and swirl for an introspective instrumental journey. Analog reigns supreme to bring an auditory vision of a future from the past.
related: QuarterHawk, Jean-Michel Jarre, Tangerine Dream, Maserati, Com Truise

name: Did It Anyway
review: Trumpeter Jamie Younkin mixes standards and her own compositions in this smoky set of songs that feature languid vocals and finessed horn playing.
related: Chet Baker, Chris Botti, Diana Krall

name: The Creation Factory
label: Lolipop
review: A pitch perfect replica of what made the British Invasion so formidable. Face-melting fuzz, underwater cathedral organs, warbling vocal harmonies, and so much more.
related: The Rolling Stones, The Brian Jonestown Massacre, The Jessica Fletchers

name: Kazuashita
label: 4AD
review: An intense mix of international flavors and electronic treatments, this album is an exotic transcendental journey across imaginary foreign lands.
related: Cocteau Twins, Beats Antique, Medicine Drum, Slowdive

name: Chosen Family
label: Lame-O
review: Rock anthems filled with quirky bits of beat and string, layered with some honey-toned vocals and surging guitars.
related: Speedy Ortiz, Courtney Barnett, Liz Phair

name: Destroy The Sun
label: Swoon
review: Driving indie guitar rock with extra-strength riffs and detailed dynamics, great harmonies, and memorable hooks.
related: Pavement, Superchunk, The Vaccines

name: Yolk In The Fur
label: Tiny Engines
review: Alternative rock with a tinge of Americana, the perfect thing to eat up miles and miles of road trip.
related: Echo and the Bunnymen, Stornoway, War on Drugs

name: Bell House
label: Polyvinyl
review: Very understated, yet completely engaging. Shy Boys live up to their name with this collection of softly-strummed, gently-tapped, whisper-harmonized indie basement gems.
related: Stephen Malkmus, Real Estate, Yo La Tengo

name: Lo La Ru
label: Ivy League
review: Fantastic Aussie rock-pop with a lot of variety, each song having its own strange melodic structure and personality.
related: Cage The Elephant, Jellyfish, Born Ruffians

name: Someday Everything Will Be Fine
label: Merge
review: Fast-forward punk, with the sort of edge that comes from the current DIY movement, and an unknown spice that makes the songs stand out from your standard barrage of fuzzed out chords and beats.
related: Social Distortion, Parquet Courts, The Oblivians, Bad Brains

name: ATW
label: New West
review: A rollicking ride through rock and roll’s back roads, with fuzzed-out riffing coming on way too loud for the stereo. Good times.
related: Led Zeppelin, Melvins, Low Frequency In Stereo, Queens of the Stone Age

name: Bambi
label: Grand Jury
review: Nicely done collection of funky pop, or poppy funk.
related: Dr. Dog, Cage The Elephant, Grand Analog

name: Time n’ Place
label: Polyvinyl
review: The off-kilter combination of glossy vaguely Japanese pop and glitching vaguely Japanese noise treatments make for an interesting mix.
related: Boyracer, Robyn, Poppy

name: TPC
label: Dine Alone
review: Solid collection of guitar-forward indie rock.
related: Pulp, The Church, Metric

name: Baby Grand
label: Merge
review: Swirling with electronic highlights, these emotional songs provide multiple layers, angelic choruses, and expressive lyrics.
related: My Morning Jacket, New Pornographers, Death Cab for Cutie

name: Degauss
review: Angular and glitchy while remaining melodic, this is a labyrinthine set of electronic compositions inviting attention to detail or outright zoning out.
related: Mouse on Mars, Tangerine Dream, Aphex Twin

name: Sun Machine
label: Grand Jury
review: Like chocolate-covered potato chips, this mixture of disparate ingredients sounds unlikely but sounds delicious.
related: Metric, Portishead, Jamiroquai, Tom Tom Club

name: The Diet
label: Sub Pop
review: A solid effort filled with gently sparkling guitar lines and subtle hooks, this manages to sound completely retro and current at the same time.
related: The Zombies, George Harrison, Smith Westerns

name: Black Dog In My Path
label: Double Double Whammy
review: Despite the name, this is understated and minimalistic, with sparse instruments and a haunting voice floating on top.
related: This Mortal Coil, Laura Gibson, Swans

name: A Wonderful Beast
label: K
review: It’s a fun party with Johnson, with his deep deep voice, laconic tone, and a boogie-down attitude from the Black Keys’ Patrick Carney
related: Dub Narcotic Sound System, Tom Tom Club, Beat Happening, The Black Keys

name: Sick Thoughts
label: Goner
review: Short blasts of punk fury. Many unsafe tracks, but the rest are a lot good quick fun.
related: Ramones, Misfits, Agent Orange

name: Performance
label: City Slang
review: A modern amalgam of fuzz, psychedelia, baroque pop, and over-the-top production, filled with hooks baited with earworms.
related: Pond, T. Rex, Foxygen, The Black Keys

name: I’ve Tortured You Long Enough
label: Sub Pop
review: Very carefully constructed selection of cavernous compositions studded with a grandiose feel, fine detail, and moody lyrics.
related: Arcade Fire, Suede, Pulp

name: Last Building Burning
label: Carpark
review: Great set of non-stop rocking from this one-man-band which turned into a full-blown outfit.
related: Rocket From The Crypt, Jawbreaker, Portugal! The Man

name: Your Moral Superior
label: Goner
review: Fast and furious punk blasts that are over by the time you catch up with the hook, keeping true to the Ramones’ quarter-mile aesthetic
related: Misfits, The Way-Outs, Ramones, The Dickies

name: Goners
label: Barsuk
review: Sparse and haunting, this minimal acoustic approach works well with Gibson’s unique fairy vocals.
related: Joanna Newsom, Jessca Hoop, Waxahatchie

name: Bird Streets
label: Omnivore
review: Smart guitar pop never goes out of style, and sharp lyrics make it all the better.
related: Jason Falkner, Death Cab For Cutie, XTC

name: Year of the Black Dog
review: Dark and bombastic, this is full of dragged-out ballads and dramatic pauses for moody rainy evenings
related: Nick Cave, Gallon Drunk

name: Meta Meta Etc.
review: Diverse mix of influences, from synth pop to hip hop to plain old indie rock.
related: The Postal Service, Tears for Fears, The Decembrists

name: Marauder
label: Marauder
review: Overthinking garage rock never goes out of style, and Interpol continues to put out albums that sound just like Interpol.
related: The Strokes, The Yeah Yeah Yeahs, Midnight Oil

name: Negro Swan
label: Domino
review: This is a smooth collection of beats and grooves filled with intricate chord work and surprising vocals.
related: Steely Dan, De La Soul, The Dirty Projectors, A Tribe Called Quest

name: Elastic Days
label: Sub Pop
review: A next-generation Neil Young, J Mascis blends massive guitar riffs, introspective lyrics, and a whiny delivery to great effect.
related: Neil Young, Dinosaur Jr., Sebadoh

name: Weed Garden EP
label: Sub Pop
review: A brief taste of Iron and Wine’s evolving style, filling out the expected introspective strumming with updated production and a fuller “band” feel.
related: Nick Drake, Wilco, Yo La Tengo

name: Black Velvet
label: Daptone
review: Posthumous release for this powerhouse soul singer. Perfect for a ‘70s cop drama.
related: Marvin Gaye, Otis Redding, Sam Cooke

name: Give Up The Gold
review: Thoughtful and delicate, this collection of songs features a variety of near-pastoral pop tunes.
related: Real Estate, The Monolith, Ben Folds

name: I’ll Sing
label: Lame-O
review: A distinctive voice and a careful meandering through the forests between Americana and indie rock make this a memorable set of songs.
related: Shannon Wright, Joanna Newsom, Jessca Hoop

name: Spencer Sings The Hits
label: In The Red
review: Spencer delivers another trash-talkin’, leg-humpin’, hip-grindin’ album in his particular inimitable style.
related: The Cramps, The Oblivians, Pussy Galore

name: We Are Electrocution
label: Burger
review: Short blasts of raw fury, seething with rage, dirty keyboards, and quite a lot of fun.
related: Rondelles, Brainiac, Oblivians

name: Double Negative
label: Sub Pop
review: This is the old Low turned up to 15. All hail the new Low! Note: This is very noisy and distorted. The machinery is not acting up.
related: Cowboy Junkies, Sunn O))), This Mortal Coil, Brian Eno

name: Digital Garbage
label: Sub Pop
review: The Neanderthals of the Seattle “grunge” sound remain in top form with eleven angry, buzzing indictments of modern living.
related: The Sonics, The Stooges, Nirvana

name: [untitled]
label: Run For Cover
review: Somewhat screamy post-punk filled with jagged stabs of guitar and a thundering rhythm section that casually locks in weirdly-metered fills.
related: McClusky, Fugazi, Pinback

name: R U OK?
review: Strutting around in Seventies duds, these songs get to the heart of the matter in 9 mile-per-gallon, leaded-gas-only style.
related: Led Zeppelin, White Denim, Wolfmother

name: Dose Your Dreams
label: Merge
review: You can call them EFFED UP if you like. A solid and expansive set of music that draws from psychedelia, hardcore, punk, rough-cut ska, and many more.
related: The Mekons, Buzzcocks, The Mighty Mighty Bosstones

name: Some People I Know
label: Compass
review: If you like bands with Brothers in the name, the kind that pluck guitars, plunk banjos, and sing in close harmonies, here’s some more great stuff.
related: The Moore Brothers, Simon and Garfunkel, Avett Brothers

name: Wasteland
label: Mach Club
review: Another all-out rock-and-roll assault from Japan … they never get bored and neither do I.
related: Zoobombs, Black Crowes, Melvins

name: Laughing With Bad Teeth
review: The macabre sounds of The Bad Man will appeal to those who like dark carnivals and shadowy ringmasters rasping out bits of polka, sea shanty, ska, and more.
related: Man Man, Tom Waits, Mischief Brew, World/Inferno Friendship Society

name: Skiff
label: Spiritual Pajamas
review: Words like “rollicking”, “thumping”, and “boisterous” apply to this fun mix of blues, boogie, and mystery meats.
related: Ween, Marshall Crenshaw, Mano Negra, Oranga Tanga

name: Dionysus
label: PAIS
review: An epic tale set to music, and a whirlwind tour of world musics.
related: This Mortal Coil, Cocteau Twins

name: Art of Doubt
label: MMI
review: With Emily Haines’ expressive vocals standing proud and up front, this is a collection of catchy singalong dance rock anthems.
related: Garbage, Lush, Le Tigre, Til Tuesday

name: See Now and How
label: K
review: What kind of raving madman discotheque is this? I don’t care that the singer yells like a man stuck in a tarpit, I’m staying for the groove.
related: Dub Narcotic Sound System, The Make-Up, Nick Cave

name: They Made Her A Criminal
label: Super Secret
review: High octane fuel for your sonic funnycar, this is a set of guitar driven fuzzy twang, straddling the line between country and rock but doing it sideways and lots of attitude.
related: Trespassers W, Buddy Holly, The Gomers

name: UN Article 14
review: These lush harmonies with a sharp pop sensibility are hiding a set of biting and insightful lyrics.
related: The Kinks, Spinto Band, Born Ruffians, Robb Benson

name: Outer Peace
label: Carpark
review: The beat rules supreme, the instrumentation is slinky, the vocals are coaxing you to the dance floor, and the whole thing says you’re going to be up all night.
related: Panda Bear, VHS Or Beta, Tom Tom Club, Jamiroquai

name: Future Ruins
label: Dangerbird
review: Hailing from the original wave of shoegaze, the band delivers the expected dosage of swooping guitar amidst dream-state vocals and rock rhythms
related: Ride, My Bloody Valentine, Failure

name: Power Chords
label: Merge
review: Punchy and punch drunk laments wrapped in glorious blankets of fuzz and overgained vocals.
related: Bracket, Ty Segall, Hanni Al-Khatib

name: Ladytron
label: !K7
review: Eminently danceable and frequently dark, this is what robots put on to seduce each other
related: Lush, Garbage, Stereolab

name: Buoys
label: Domino
review: Multilayered excursions into the analog and digital realms, blurring everything into a psychoactive tapestry.
related: Animal Collective, Dirty Projectors, hollAnd

name: Beat My Distance
label: Luminelle
review: Heavenly melodies, luscious harmonies, over-chorused guitar jangles, and a sunny sparkling delivery make this suitable for ‘90s 4AD fans.
related: Tennis, The Bird and the Bee, Belly

name: Some Good Lives
label: Dutch
review: Solid songs that mix a generous dollop of traditional country elements with a big scoop of indie pop.
related: Palehound, Jenny Lewis, Listing Ship

name: Undone At 31
label: Merge
review: Martin is baring his soul, exposing his darkest secrets in a whispered croon, here inside this closet.
related: Twerps, Lou Reed, The Mountain Goats

name: Birthday
label: Bella Union
review: Norwegian death pop worthy of Dave Brubeck with its catchy off-meter hooks takes you through a rainbow-colored tunnel of sharp candy shards.
related: Deerhoof, Low Frequency In Stereo, Kero Kero Bonito, Yeah Yeah Yeahs

name: Effluxion
label: Merge
review: An unusually sharp pop sensibility keeps this outfit from blending into the background, with rough-and-tumble rocking.
related: Cage the Elephant, Heartless Bastards

name: Zam
label: Greenway
review: Original psychedelic riff rock is an oxymoron … what matters is the ability to get you off your seat, which this band has aplenty
related: Oh Sees, King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard, Brainiac

name: Till I Burn Up
label: Anti
review: Quite the military parade, a non-stop set of marching songs for liquid guitar and drum machine.
related: Ratatat, Brian Eno, Brian May

name: Pony
label: Sub Pop
review: Old fashioned haunted country music… Orville Peck howls, croons, and yodels in a way that is extremely dramatic, yet never quite goes over the top.
related: Parker and Lily, Roy Orbison, Nick Cave

name: The Cedars
label: Native Cat
review: A meticulously crafted release, with extreme attention to detail and a great sense of cohesion despite a wide variety of sounds… destined to be a classic.
related: Dirty Projectors, The Mountain Goats, The Microphones

name: Sweet Delirium
label: Allswell
review: Sparkling gems, with great ‘70s AM radio hooks and harmonies and incredibly detailed production.
related: Owsley, Mohair, Dr. Dog

name: Dogrel
label: Partisan
review: Razor-sharp post-punk delivered with a disaffected Irish brogue. Very smart on many levels, recalling The Fall when they were at their most musical
related: Art Brut, Gang of Four, The Fall, Eugene McGuiness

name: The Budos Band V
label: Daptone
review: A completely international approach to music, with influences ranging from funk to afrobeat to Balkan brass, blurring genres and locations in a glorious celebration of groove.
related: The James Taylor Quartet, Antibalas, Balkan Beat Box

name: Real Life
label: Park The Van
review: Clever pop songs, filled with good hooks and ready for mixtapes
related: Vampire Weekend, Eels, Panda Bear

name: U.F.O.F.
label: 4AD
review: Mysteriously complicated folk music, with the sort of lush guitar arrangements and ethereal vocals that brought 4AD to prominence 30+ years ago.
related: Buck Meek, Throwing Muses, Jessca Hoop

label: Hardly Art
review: Focused on the guitar but not so much in keeping things in normal scale systems, this band punches through some heavy dissonance to make for memorable riffs.
related: Failure, Stephen Malkmus, Archers of Loaf

name: This Mess Is A Place
label: Sub Pop
review: It’s catchy pop punk, and it’s clearly female-powered, but there’s more here than rainbow stickers, glorious hooks and riffs, and big puffy girl handwriting.
related: Cub, Dressy Bessy, Veruca Salt

name: Lowdown Ways
label: Yep Roc
review: Having the word “daddy” in your band’s name is a tough bar to clear, and these guys have just the type of delta blues sleaze to make it over easy.
related: The Legendary Shack Shakers, Hillstomp, North Mississippi Allstars

name: In Shambles
label: Pig Baby
review: This Florida garage-rock combo provides complete party in audio format, featuring regrettable debauchery, frenzied dancing, and a desire to not have the fun ever end.
related: The Woggles, The Swingin’ Neckbreakers, The Sonics

name: The Holy Spell…
label: FAT Wreck Chords
review: Once a Ramone always a Ramone, one supposes, but this is closer to Southern California chug-core than gritty Queens punk. Nonetheless, a fun time.
related: The Ramones, Social Distortion, Rancid

label: Goner
review: Mosh pit melodies for Daleks. Aggressive hardcore beats, with theremin, snarky bass, and chanting vocals instead of distorted guitar.
related: Gang of Four, Mission of Burma, Black Flag

name: Gastwerk Saboteurs
label: Saustex
review: After serving 11 years backing Mark E. Smith, this bands breaks out into a dark rock sound, thrilling with its edgy energy and monster riffing.
related: Quicksand, Failure, Killing Joke

name: Persuasion System
label: Ghostly
review: One time, this robot arm at the plant started going haywire, flailing around, it was going to kill someone. We played it some Com Truise and it calmed right down.
related: Moby, Brian Eno, Tangerine Dream

name: Reward
label: Mexican Summer
review: Supremely introspective and carefully arranged, this collection of songs that range from lushly orchestrated to uncomfortably angular makes for a great moody journey
related: Laurie Anderson, Joanna Newsom, Micachu and the Shapes

name: Reggae Now!
label: Pirates Press
review: It’s not ska, and it’s not rocksteady, but it’s definitely Jamaican and powerfully dancy — you can call it “69 Reggae” after the year of its initial popularity.
related: The Slackers, Madness, The Clash

name: Invocation / Conversations
label: Love Is EZ
review: Delicious pop conconctions, loaded with clever production flourishes and infectious melodies wrapped around a soulful core.
related: Hall and Oates, The Bird and the Bee, Jellyfish

name: And Now for the Watchamacallit
label: Marathon Artists
review: The name promises so much, and the band overdelivers. The continent of Australia is awash in lysergic excursions lately, and this is one of the finest.
related: King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard, Ty Segall, Pond

name: How Am I Not Myself?
label: Danger Collective
review: Hot-as-fire punk disco party with a raging saxophone and urgent female vocals.
related: Le Tigre, Obliterati, Palberta

name: Originals
label: NPG
review: Songs that the Purple One wrote for others, as performed by the person who wrote them. A good set of well-produced demos, but nothing that should have been released a long time ago and mostly of historical interest.
related: Morris Day and the Time, The Bangles, Sinead O’Conner

name: Paradise
label: Company
review: A set of guitar-centered mid-tempo numbers that live somewhere in the region staked out by jazz, funk, and soul.
related: Mac DeMarco, Chuck Mangione, Tortoise

name: Black Friday
label: Polyvinyl
review: Nice indie guitar sounds, with whispery vocals and a meandering melodic spirit.
related: Liz Phair, Waxahatchie, Soccer Mommy

name: Schlagenheim
label: Rough Trade
review: Insistent angular weirdfunk, songs that sound like tape loops that have fallen out of order and yet maintain a diligent desire to be songs.
related: Art Brut, The Dismemberment Plan, The Fall

name: A Bathfull of Ecstasy
label: Domino
review: At one time, electronic soul felt like the future of music, but here is Hot Chip doing just the same thing in 2019 and it feels nostalgic.
related: Pet Shop Boys, Erasure, Depeche Mode

name: Automat
label: Sub Pop
review: This is heavy pounding music that is pounding and heavy, also distorted, and pounding and heavy. Somewhat repetitive, but some of us like it like that, and pounding, and heavy.
related: Bass Drum of Death, Night Whip, Melvins

name: Now We Are Timeless
label: Merge
review: Incredibly smart power pop overflowing with fat analog synth lines and enough earworms and hooks to launch a sonic fishing expedition.
related: Faith No More, Weezer, Spoon

name: A People’s History of Gauche
label: Merge
review: Spiky little numbers filled with quicksilver guitar lines, the occasional horn section, punky drums and bass, and sing-song female vocals that sound like someone making fun of their bullies.
related: Chicks on Speed, Le Tigre, French Vanilla

name: Showboat Honey
label: Sub Pop
review: This is salty, and tangy, and spicy, and sweet, like the musical equivalent of a Mexican tamarind candy. It sounds so Sixties and Seventies that it must be from Today.
related: Ty Segall, T. Rex, Hanni Al Khatib

name: Tell All Your Friend
review: It’s indie pop, but it’s also heavily inflected with soul, country, R&B, western swing, and a bad attitude.
related: Supergrass, The Sadies, Islands

name: Reader As Detective
label: Polyvinyl
review: Electronic drums, layers and filigrees of keyboards, and falsetto choruses make for some glossy synthesizer soul music that wouldn’t be out of place on a late Eighties dance floor.
related: Hot Chip, Orchestral Maneuvers in the Dark, STRFKR

name: Dudu
label: Captured Tracks
review: WIth their minimalist riffing, straight ahead drumming, and disaffected vocals, this band sounds so much like Parquet Courts I had to check that it wasn’t a side project
related: Parquet Courts, Wire, The Minutemen

name: Hotel Last Resort
label: PIAS
review: This is kept stripped-down and acerbic, completely aligned with the band’s original punk-folk ethic.

name: Falling
label: Hardly Art
review: It’s an old recipe but it never fails: Mix some high-energy guitar rock, the kind with chuggy riffs, and put a female voice strong enough to withstand the maelstrom on top.
related: Tacocat, Garbage, The Muffs

name: Chains Are Broken
label: New West
review: Americana with a punk-ass louche attitude always makes for a good bawdy time.
related: Mumford and Sons, The Bath Salt Zombies, Bad Livers

name: This Is Not A Safe Place
label: Wichita
review: With so many new bands discovering and repurposing the swirling sounds of shoegaze, it’s no wonder original trailblazer is back with another collection of guitar-heavy near-instrumentals.
related: My Bloody Valentine, Curve, Slowdive

name: Power
label: New West
review: The nostalgic approach strikes gold, as this goes back to the heyday of ‘60s girl groups, with heavenly vocals, shimmering production, and deep hooks that you will have a hard time shaking off.
related: The Chiffons, Amy Winehouse, The Donettes

name: From Home
label: Yep Roc
review: Straight and true from the source of power pop, the Rubinoos deliver carefully crafted AM radio gems filled with detailed arrangements, sharp turns of melody, and glorious harmonious infectious hooks.
related: The Raspberries, The Shins, The Flamin’ Groovies

name: Beyond The Door
label: Merge
review: The clown kings of LA punk are back with their (so-far) commercially-unviable yet overwhelmingly fulfilling mix of bad attitude and party rock.
related: The Lemonheads, Cheap Trick, The Posies

name: Anak Ko
label: Polyvinyl
review: Understated but solid set of songs with a strong female vocal presence. There’s a loving interlocking of guitar, bass, and keyboard lines that gives the music a rich and interesting texture.
related: Pinback, This Is The Kit, Mo Kenney

name: Chronologic
label: Le Plan
review: Caravan Palace uses old-fashioned swing music for its digital building blocks and emerges with something like audio caffeine
related: Shantel, Dee-lite, The Bird and the Bee

name: Twelve Nudes
label: Bella Union
review: Furman sounds like he’s barely keeping it together as he blasts through a set of classic rockers, loaded with riffs and swagger.
related: Ty Segall, Ron Gallo, Destroyer

name: Neon Brown
label: 4AD
review: Awkward jams that nonetheless stick in your head on repeat, with highly-detailed production and a decidedly noir feel.
related: Dirty Projectors, Blood Orange, Portishead

name: Close It Quietly
label: Sub Pop
review: Sweetness and sunshine without overstepping into cloying and saccharine, with chiming guitars and subtle keyboard hooks providing a bed for clear female croonings.
related: Lush, Belle and Sebastian, Dressy Bessy

name: The Bobby Tenderloin Universe
label: Keeping On
review: The cowboy bandwagon is in full effect as Bobby Tenderloin takes us into a rough-and-tumble universe filled with tragic and entertaining Western tropes.
related: Orville Peck, Johnny Cash, Ween

name: Free
label: Loma Vista
review: Still burning bright, this is an interesting collection of material that has Pop veering from spoken word jazz to menacing indie rock. It’s not fast and loud, but it sure is sneering and in your face.
related: Tom Waits, Ken Nordine, Portishead

name: Ollie Oxen Free
review: Pop jigsaw symphonies, incongruous bits and pieces of songs interlocking together into a hypnotic cascade of rhythms, melodies, and harmonies.
related: Pop Canon, Heavy Vegetable, Apples In Stereo

name: Lookout Low
label: Grand Jury
review: Indie rock is evergreen, especially when mixed with elements of psychedelia and southern boogie.
related: The Band, The Skiffle Players, Spinto Band

name: Today
label: 30th Century
review: An extremely diverse outing, with songs cutting across many genres but sharing a generally sunny and engaging disposition, delivered with casual ease and filled with memorable hooks.
related: Je Suis France, Gorky’s Zygotic Minci, Donovan

name: Pictures of Pictures
label: Dangerbird
review: Solid guitar and keyboard pop, on the gentle dreamy side, with whispery singing and sharp arrangements.
related: Tame Impala, Toro y Moi, Papas Fritas

name: Beneath The Eyrie
label: Infectious
review: Reminiscent of Bossanova-era songwriting, the band continues to make use of twisted lyrics and unexpected melodic flourishes to further iterate on their iconic sound.
related: The Breeders, Frank Black, Violent Femmes

name: Bobbie’s A Girl
label: Merge
review: Gentle music for a pastoral New Zealand scene, with tappity drums and soft jangles playfully jostling understated vocals.
related: The Clean, Alfie, Real Estate

name: Ma
label: Sire
review: Orchestral and very intelligent singer-songwriter music that yields some very intricate arrangements without being overwhelming and overwrought.
related: Sufjan Stevens, Sondre Lerche, Edwin Collins

name: Ain’t Quite Like That
label: MaHatMa
review: A mix of country, western swing, rockabilly, and various other semi-compatible genres, paired with seductive vocals and plenty of musical swagger.
related: Hot Club of Cowtown, Post-Modern Jukebox, Asylum Street Spankers

name: Paraty, Brazil
label: OAR
review: Intensely layered psychedelic outing from Brazil, with a collection of instrumentals and softly-sibilant Portuguese designed to transport you on a multicolored rainbow of spices.
related: Os Mutantes, Oh Sees, Boogarins

name: Natural Disguise
label: Congrats
review: Forward-looking dance funk, the kind of music that immediately makes you grab the closest person by the wrist and drag them to the dance floor.
related: Vulfpeck, Broncho, The Make-Up

name: Primitive Feelings
label: Hook + Prayer
review: A bit of a throwback to the sound of late ‘80s Manchester and subsequent British psychedelic pop, presented with a pulsating dance beat and dreamy multilayered vocals.
related: The Stone Roses, Wooden Shjips, James

name: Sleepyhead
label: Hardly Art
review: Crafty pop punk, brimming over with chunky guitars, layered female vocals, and lots of sneering.
related: Bully, The Breeders, The Muffs

name: Headspace
label: Greenway
review: Verring wildly from soft-funk to outright garage fuzz, this wouldn’t be out of place coming out the AM radio and windows of a 1974 Maverick.
related: Swarming Branch, The Kinks, The Schizophonics

name: DSVII
label: Mute
review: Very low-key instrumentals, dependent more on subtle dynamics than on any sort of recognizable or repeatable melodic content. Quite intellectual and meditative.
related: Air, Plaid, Brian Eno

name: Memory
label: Polyvinyl
review: The girl group aesthetic survives, drenched in spring reverb and distant crooning, and it’s not just unscathed, it’s very agitated and ready to rip throats.
related: La Luz, Phil Spector, Surfer Blood

name: Entre Los Dos
label: Tender Loving Empire
review: An exuberant mix of weird rock, Latin influences, and mysterious elements, resulting in some sort of white hot fusion.
related: Ozomatli, Captain Beefheart, David Byrne

name: Two Hands
label: 4AD
review: A distinctive female voice fronting a standard indie combo is not the most exciting formula, but Big Thief has a penchant for weird flourishes and unexpected changes that keeps things interesting
related: Bettie Serveert, Fleetwood Mac, Rubblebucket

name: Bigger Than Life
label: Sacred Bones
review: Analog synthesizers still sound like the shiny plastic future, even if they’re likely older than the young man fiddling with them in the California sunshine.
related: Magnetic Fields, Orchestral Maneuvers in the Dark, Liima

name: Beautiful Country
label: Ramseur
review: Very agreeable folk pop, with clever harmonies and sharp hooks making it the sort of music to bring on a road trip.
related: Babe Rainbow, Spinto Band, Jon + Roy

name: Junior
label: Sub Pop
review: Francophonic guitar attaque, brimming with chiming arpeggios, complicated stringular interplay, and words beyond comprehension but not understanding.
related: Ride, Failure, Parquet Courts

name: The Studio Recordings
label: Loop Recordings
review: A disparate assemblage of New Zealand musicians yielding a disparate assemblage of styles, from dusty ballads to reggae whimsy to downright funk.
related: Fiona Apple, The Everly Brothers, North Mississippi Allstars

name: HaitiaNola
label: Cumbancha
review: A simmering stew of cross-cultural influences, as the African and Creole sounds of Haiti blend with New Orleans’ own unique funk. The results are as energetic and danceable as you’d expect
related: Trombone Shorty, Buraka Som Sistema, Anders Osborne

name: Networker
label: Sub Pop
review: A strange confluence of influences, with a lot of dynamic arrangements and plenty of weird hooks that shouldn’t work but are lethally effective.
related: Pavement, Steely Dan, Pinback

name: Bright Blue
label: Oscar St.
review: Delightfully twee songs, filled with shimmering melodies, sparkling production, and heavenly choruses.
related: Tennis, The Sundays, The Bird and the Bee

name: Dark Thoughts
label: Tender Loving Empire
review: Psychedelic surf music from Portland, impossibly catchy and off-the-cuff, built on riffs that bludgeon you like a deliciously dense spongecake.
related: Oh Sees, Velvet Underground, Vivian Girls

name: Cool To Who
label: Outside
review: Sounding a lot like the heyday of 1990s indie dream pop, Walrus keeps it a little spicy if not very distinctive.
related: Rubblebucket, Big Thief, Veruca Salt

name: Sings The Police
label: American Laundromat
review: The source material is brilliant, but the interpretations are so uneven that it’s more like “Juliana Hatfield’s Wax Museum of Songs by The Police”.
related: The Police, Juliana Hatfield

name: True False
label: Seeland
review: Layers of samples, voices, music, found audio, sound effects, and other bizarre elements make up these haunting compositions from the masters of audio collage.
related: The Evolution Control Committee, Bran Flakes

name: A Jump from the High Dive
label: Double Double Whammy
review: Another solo pop genius wunderkind, blasting it out of the water with a summery mix of rock and psychedelia.
related: Beck, Jason Falkner, Telekinesis
